metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and explain theoretically and practically diffraction as the directional spread of various frequencies with reference to different gap width or obstacle size, including the qualitative effect of changing the λ/w ratio, and apply this to limitations of imaging using electromagnetic waves

diffraction_definition.name: Diffraction Definition
diffraction_definition.formula: Spreading of waves around obstacles/through gaps
diffraction_definition.correct: Diffraction is the spreading of waves as they pass through gaps or around obstacles. It is a wave property that distinguishes waves from particles.

the bending of waves due to speed change.fix: Diffraction is spreading, not bending due to speed change. Refraction involves changing media.
the bending of waves due to speed change.action: Compare: diffraction = spreading through gaps; refraction = bending at boundaries.

the bouncing of waves off surfaces.fix: Diffraction involves waves spreading, not bouncing back.
the bouncing of waves off surfaces.action: Draw a wave going through a gap—it spreads out, not bounces.

waves combining to form patterns.fix: Diffraction is spreading; interference is the result of combining waves.
waves combining to form patterns.action: Diffraction causes spreading first, then interference creates the pattern.

persistent.gap: You are confusing diffraction with other wave phenomena.
persistent.action: Make a table: diffraction (spreading), refraction (bending at boundary), reflection (bouncing), interference (combining).

diffraction_ratio.name: Diffraction Ratio
diffraction_ratio.correct: The extent of diffraction is proportional to the ratio of wavelength to gap width (λ/w). Larger ratios produce more spreading.

λ × w.error: Wrong operation. It's a ratio (division), not multiplication.
λ × w.fix: Diffraction ∝ λ/w means wavelength divided by gap width.
λ × w.action: Think: bigger wavelength OR smaller gap increases spreading.

w/λ.error: Inverted. Wavelength is on top, gap width on bottom.
w/λ.fix: λ/w, not w/λ. Bigger ratio = more diffraction.
w/λ.action: Remember: λ on top. If λ increases, ratio increases, spreading increases.

λ + w.error: Wrong operation. It's division, not addition.
λ + w.fix: The ratio λ/w compares wavelength to gap size.
λ + w.action: You cannot add wavelength and gap width—different physical meanings.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how the diffraction ratio works.
persistent.action: Calculate λ/w for three scenarios. Rank them by diffraction amount.

significant_diffraction_condition.name: Significant Diffraction Condition
significant_diffraction_condition.correct: Significant diffraction occurs when the wavelength is comparable to or larger than the gap width (λ/w ≳ 1). When λ/w ≪ 1, diffraction is negligible.

λ/w ≪ 1.error: That condition produces minimal diffraction, not significant.
λ/w ≪ 1.fix: λ/w ≪ 1 means wavelength much smaller than gap—wave passes straight through.
λ/w ≪ 1.action: Think: if the gap is huge compared to wavelength, the wave barely notices the edges.

λ/w = 0.error: Zero ratio is impossible and would mean no diffraction.
λ/w = 0.fix: Significant diffraction requires λ/w to be close to 1 or greater.
λ/w = 0.action: λ/w cannot equal zero unless wavelength is zero—impossible for any wave.

w/λ ≳ 1.error: Inverted condition. That means gap is larger than wavelength—minimal diffraction.
w/λ ≳ 1.fix: Use λ/w, not w/λ. For significant spreading, λ/w must be large.
w/λ ≳ 1.action: If gap is 10× the wavelength, diffraction is tiny. Flip the ratio mentally.

persistent.gap: You are applying the diffraction condition backwards.
persistent.action: Remember: λ comparable to w → significant spreading. Calculate examples to verify.

wavelength_effect.name: Wavelength Effect on Diffraction
wavelength_effect.correct: Longer wavelengths produce more diffraction through the same gap because the λ/w ratio increases.

shorter wavelengths diffract more.error: Opposite. Shorter wavelength reduces λ/w, reducing diffraction.
shorter wavelengths diffract more.fix: Longer wavelength = larger λ/w = more spreading.
shorter wavelengths diffract more.action: Compare red and violet light through the same gap—red spreads more.

wavelength has no effect.error: Wavelength is directly in the diffraction ratio.
wavelength has no effect.fix: Diffraction ∝ λ/w, so wavelength strongly affects spreading.
wavelength has no effect.action: Double the wavelength, double the λ/w ratio, significantly more spreading.

only gap width matters.error: Both wavelength AND gap width affect diffraction.
only gap width matters.fix: The ratio λ/w includes both. Change either, change the diffraction.
only gap width matters.action: The formula tells you: λ on top, w on bottom—both matter equally.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how wavelength affects diffraction.
persistent.action: Compare FM radio (long λ) and mobile signals (short λ) around obstacles. Which diffracts more?

gap_width_effect.name: Gap Width Effect on Diffraction
gap_width_effect.correct: Smaller gaps produce more diffraction because the λ/w ratio increases. Larger gaps allow waves to pass with minimal spreading.

larger gaps produce more diffraction.error: Opposite. Larger gap reduces λ/w, reducing diffraction.
larger gaps produce more diffraction.fix: Smaller gap = larger λ/w = more spreading.
larger gaps produce more diffraction.action: A doorway diffracts sound. A stadium entrance does not—gap is too large.

gap width has no effect.error: Gap width is in the denominator of λ/w—it has major effect.
gap width has no effect.fix: Halve the gap width, double the λ/w ratio.
gap width has no effect.action: Compare waves through a 1 m gap vs 10 m gap—very different spreading.

only wavelength matters.error: Both wavelength AND gap width affect diffraction equally.
only wavelength matters.fix: The ratio λ/w requires both values. Either can be changed.
only wavelength matters.action: To increase diffraction: increase λ OR decrease w OR both.

persistent.gap: You are confused about how gap width affects diffraction.
persistent.action: Hold up your hand with fingers together vs spread apart. Which gap diffracts sound more?

frequency_wavelength_relationship.name: Frequency-Wavelength Relationship
frequency_wavelength_relationship.correct: For a given wave speed, higher frequency means shorter wavelength, and lower frequency means longer wavelength.

higher frequency means longer wavelength.error: Opposite. In v = fλ, if v is constant, f and λ are inversely related.
higher frequency means longer wavelength.fix: Higher f = shorter λ. Lower f = longer λ.
higher frequency means longer wavelength.action: Rearrange: λ = v/f. If f increases (denominator up), λ decreases.

frequency and wavelength are unrelated.error: They are linked by the wave equation v = fλ.
frequency and wavelength are unrelated.fix: For constant speed, frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional.
frequency and wavelength are unrelated.action: Check: v = fλ. If v stays constant, f↑ means λ↓.

frequency equals wavelength.error: They are different quantities with different units.
frequency equals wavelength.fix: Frequency is in Hz, wavelength is in metres. They are inversely related.
frequency equals wavelength.action: Units check: Hz × m = m/s (speed). Not equal, but linked.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength.
persistent.action: Calculate λ for f = 100 Hz and f = 200 Hz with v = 340 m/s. Compare values.

frequency_diffraction_effect.name: Frequency Effect on Diffraction
frequency_diffraction_effect.formula: Higher f → shorter λ → less diffraction
frequency_diffraction_effect.correct: Higher frequency waves diffract less because they have shorter wavelengths, reducing the λ/w ratio.

higher frequency diffracts more.error: Opposite. Higher f = shorter λ = smaller λ/w = less diffraction.
higher frequency diffracts more.fix: Low frequency sounds (bass) diffract around corners better than high frequency (treble).
higher frequency diffracts more.action: Think: why can you hear bass through walls but not high notes?

frequency has no effect on diffraction.error: Frequency determines wavelength, which directly affects diffraction.
frequency has no effect on diffraction.fix: Change frequency → change wavelength → change λ/w ratio → change diffraction.
frequency has no effect on diffraction.action: The link is: f affects λ, and λ affects diffraction.

all frequencies diffract equally.error: Different frequencies have different wavelengths, so diffract differently.
all frequencies diffract equally.fix: Lower frequencies (longer λ) diffract more through the same gap.
all frequencies diffract equally.action: FM radio (88-108 MHz) diffracts around buildings better than mobile (900+ MHz).

persistent.gap: You do not connect frequency to wavelength to diffraction.
persistent.action: Chain the logic: f↑ → λ↓ → λ/w↓ → less diffraction. Practice this chain.

imaging_resolution_limit.name: Imaging Resolution Limit
imaging_resolution_limit.correct: Diffraction limits the resolution of imaging systems. Objects smaller than the wavelength cannot be clearly resolved because the light diffracts around them.

magnification is the only limit.error: Even infinite magnification cannot overcome diffraction limits.
magnification is the only limit.fix: Diffraction blurs images of features smaller than the wavelength used.
magnification is the only limit.action: Optical microscopes cannot see atoms—light wavelength is too large.

diffraction does not affect imaging.error: Diffraction is the fundamental limit on imaging resolution.
diffraction does not affect imaging.fix: Light spreads when passing through apertures, blurring fine details.
diffraction does not affect imaging.action: Why use electron microscopes? Electrons have shorter wavelength than light.

only lens quality matters.error: Even perfect lenses are limited by diffraction.
only lens quality matters.fix: The physical nature of waves sets a resolution limit.
only lens quality matters.action: Telescope resolution depends on aperture size due to diffraction.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why diffraction limits imaging.
persistent.action: Research why electron microscopes exist—the answer is diffraction limits of light.

aperture_resolution.name: Aperture and Resolution
aperture_resolution.correct: Larger apertures reduce diffraction effects, improving resolution. This is why telescopes have large mirrors and microscopes have wide objective lenses.

smaller apertures give better resolution.error: Opposite. Smaller apertures increase λ/w, increasing diffraction blur.
smaller apertures give better resolution.fix: Larger aperture = smaller λ/w = less diffraction = sharper image.
smaller apertures give better resolution.action: Telescopes are built larger for resolution, not just light gathering.

aperture size does not affect resolution.error: Aperture is w in the λ/w ratio—directly affects diffraction.
aperture size does not affect resolution.fix: Larger w means smaller λ/w ratio, meaning less diffraction blur.
aperture size does not affect resolution.action: Compare images from a pinhole vs a large lens—pinhole is blurry.

resolution depends only on wavelength.error: Both wavelength and aperture affect the λ/w ratio.
resolution depends only on wavelength.fix: Resolution improves with shorter wavelength OR larger aperture.
resolution depends only on wavelength.action: The ratio λ/w governs diffraction. Both variables matter.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how aperture affects resolution.
persistent.action: Research the Hubble vs James Webb telescopes. Compare apertures and resolution.

shorter_wavelength_resolution.name: Shorter Wavelength Improves Resolution
shorter_wavelength_resolution.formula: Shorter λ → less diffraction → better resolution
shorter_wavelength_resolution.correct: Shorter wavelengths reduce the λ/w ratio, reducing diffraction and improving resolution. This is why electron microscopes use electrons instead of light.

longer wavelengths give better resolutio.error: Opposite. Longer λ increases λ/w, increasing diffraction blur.
longer wavelengths give better resolutio.fix: Shorter wavelength = smaller λ/w = less spreading = sharper details.
longer wavelengths give better resolutio.action: Violet light resolves finer details than red light in microscopes.

wavelength does not affect resolution.error: Wavelength is in the diffraction ratio—it directly affects resolution.
wavelength does not affect resolution.fix: λ/w determines diffraction. Smaller λ = smaller ratio = better resolution.
wavelength does not affect resolution.action: This is why X-rays and electrons are used to image atoms—short wavelengths.

all wavelengths resolve equally.error: Different wavelengths produce different amounts of diffraction.
all wavelengths resolve equally.fix: Shorter wavelengths diffract less, allowing finer detail to be resolved.
all wavelengths resolve equally.action: Compare optical vs electron microscopes—electrons have much shorter λ.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why shorter wavelengths improve resolution.
persistent.action: Calculate de Broglie wavelength of an electron vs visible light wavelength. Compare.

wave_property_evidence.name: Diffraction as Wave Evidence
wave_property_evidence.correct: Diffraction is evidence for the wave nature of light and matter. Particles travelling in straight lines would not spread around obstacles or through gaps.

particles also diffract.error: In classical physics, particles do not diffract. Only waves do.
particles also diffract.fix: Diffraction requires wave properties. Particle-like behaviour is straight-line motion.
particles also diffract.action: When electrons diffract, it proves they have wave properties.

diffraction proves light is a particle.error: Opposite. Diffraction is evidence for wave-like behaviour.
diffraction proves light is a particle.fix: Waves spread around obstacles; particles would cast sharp shadows.
diffraction proves light is a particle.action: Young's double slit uses diffraction and interference—both wave properties.

diffraction is not evidence of wave natu.error: Diffraction is a defining characteristic of waves.
diffraction is not evidence of wave natu.fix: If something diffracts, it must have wave properties.
diffraction is not evidence of wave natu.action: List wave properties: diffraction, interference, reflection, refraction. All require waves.

persistent.gap: You do not understand diffraction as wave evidence.
persistent.action: Compare how a wave and a stream of bullets would behave going through a slit.

sound_diffraction_example.name: Sound Diffraction Examples
sound_diffraction_example.correct: Low frequency sounds (bass) diffract more than high frequency sounds (treble) because they have longer wavelengths. This is why you hear bass through walls more easily.

high frequency sounds diffract more.error: Opposite. High frequency = short wavelength = less diffraction.
high frequency sounds diffract more.fix: Bass notes (low f, long λ) spread around obstacles; treble does not.
high frequency sounds diffract more.action: Why can you hear the bass from a party next door but not the vocals?

all sounds diffract equally.error: Different frequencies have different wavelengths, so diffract differently.
all sounds diffract equally.fix: A 100 Hz sound (λ ≈ 3.4 m) diffracts much more than 10 kHz (λ ≈ 3.4 cm).
all sounds diffract equally.action: Calculate wavelengths for different frequencies using v = fλ.

sound does not diffract.error: Sound is a wave and definitely diffracts.
sound does not diffract.fix: You can hear someone around a corner—that's sound diffraction.
sound does not diffract.action: Stand around a corner from a speaker. You still hear sound—diffraction.

persistent.gap: You do not understand real-world diffraction examples.
persistent.action: Listen to music from another room. Note which frequencies come through best.

imaging_limitations.title: Diffraction Limits on Imaging
imaging_limitations.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how diffraction limits imaging.

diffraction_basics.title: Mastering Diffraction Concepts
diffraction_basics.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of diffraction concepts and common misconceptions.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that diffraction is the same as refraction. However, refraction involves a change in wave {{d1}} at a boundary, while diffraction is {{d2}} around obstacles or through gaps.

imaging_limitations.title: Mastering Imaging Resolution Limits
